name: Quazepam (Doral)
summary: Quazepam is a long-acting benzodiazepine primarily prescribed for the treatment of insomnia, especially when difficulty falling or staying asleep is persistent.
description: Quazepam, marketed under the brand name Doral, is a benzodiazepine hypnotic with a relatively long half-life. It enhances the effects of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), an inhibitory neurotransmitter, resulting in sedation, muscle relaxation, and anxiolysis. It is generally used for short-term management of insomnia, particularly in patients requiring prolonged sleep maintenance.

items: Insomnia characterized by difficulty falling asleep and/or maintaining sleep

sections.text: Quazepam binds to the benzodiazepine site on the GABA-A receptor complex, enhancing the effect of GABA by increasing the frequency of chloride channel opening. This leads to neuronal hyperpolarization and CNS depression, promoting sedation and sleep.

sections.geriatric: Initiate at 7.5 mg at bedtime to reduce risk of excessive sedation and falls

sections.text: Onset: 30–60 minutes; Duration: up to 12–15 hours due to active metabolites

other: Risk of dependence and withdrawal with prolonged use
Avoid in patients with history of substance use disorder
Can cause next-day impairment—avoid hazardous activities if not fully alert

sections.pregnancy: Category X; contraindicated due to risk of fetal harm
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; avoid during breastfeeding
sections.geriatrics: Increased sensitivity and fall risk—use lowest effective dose

sections.text: Gradual dose reduction over weeks to minimize withdrawal symptoms such as rebound insomnia, anxiety, and seizures

items: Due to its long half-life, it may not be suitable for patients sensitive to next-day sedation
Intended for short-term use—typically not longer than 2–4 weeks
Avoid abrupt discontinuation to reduce withdrawal risk
